column1: One eighth of the whole population were enslaved people
column2: not distributed generally over the Union
column3: but localized in the Southern part of it. These enslaved people constituted a peculiar and powerful interest. All knew that this interest was
column5: the cause of the war. To strengthen
column7: and extend this interest was the object for which the insurgents would rend the Union
column8: even by war; while the government claimed no right to do more than to restrict the territorial enlargement of it. Neither party expected for the war
column11: which it has already attained. Neither anticipated that the cause of the conflict might cease with
column13: the conflict itself should cease. Each looked for an easier triumph
column14: and a result less fundamental and astounding. Both read the same Bible
column15: and pray to the same God; and each invokes His aid against the other.It may seem strange that any men should dare to ask a just God's assistance in wringing their bread from the sweat of other men's faces; but let us judge not that we be not judged. The prayers of both could not be answered; that of neither has been answered fully.
